natural problem: Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair.
natural solution: Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.

We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;

pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);

import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2,5)"
and h1 : "N = (6,5)"
and h2 : "P = (6,7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2,7)"
and h4 : "rotate_270_clockwise M N P Q"
and h5 : "reflect_x_1 M N P Q"
shows  "final_image Q = (2,5)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2,5)"
and h1 : "N = (6,5)"
and h2 : "P = (6,7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2,7)"
and h4 : "rotate_270_clockwise M N P Q"
and h5 : "reflect_x_1 M N P Q"
shows  "final_image Q = (2,5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given four points in the plane, M(2,5), N(6,5), P(6,7), and Q(2,7). If you rotate the points 270 degrees clockwise and then reflect them over the line x=1, what are the coordinates of the final image of Q? The final answer is (2,5).

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate_270_clockwise_around_M (Q)"
and h5 : "Q = reflect_across_line_x_1 (R)"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate_270_clockwise_around_M (Q)"
and h5 : "Q = reflect_across_line_x_1 (R)"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that points M, N, P, and Q have the coordinates (2,5), (6,5), (6,7), and (2,7) respectively, and point R is a result of a 270-degree clockwise rotation around point M from point Q. Further, point Q is obtained by reflecting point R across the line x=1. What are the coordinates of Q? The final answer is (2,5).

a_2.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real*real"
and rotate :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
and reflect :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "M = (2,5)"
and h1 : "N = (6,5)"
and h2 : "P = (6,7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2,7)"
and h4 : "rotate M = M"
and h5 : "rotate N = N"
and h6 : "rotate P = P"
and h7 : "rotate Q = Q'"
and h8 : "reflect Q' = (2,5)"
shows  "Q' = (2,5)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem 
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real*real"
and rotate :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
and reflect :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "M = (2,5)"
and h1 : "N = (6,5)"
and h2 : "P = (6,7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2,7)"
and h4 : "rotate M = M"
and h5 : "rotate N = N"
and h6 : "rotate P = P"
and h7 : "rotate Q = Q'"
and h8 : "reflect Q' = (2,5)"
shows  "Q' = (2,5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given four points M, N, P, Q, where M is at (2,5), N is at (6,5), P is at (6,7) and Q is at (2,7). Suppose we have a rotation transformation that leaves M, N, P unchanged, but moves Q to point Q'. If Q' is reflected over the x-axis to point (2,5), find the coordinates of Q'. The final answer is (2,5).

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "Q' = rotate_270 M (reflect Q)"
shows  "Q' = (2, 5)"

Note: Here we assume that the functions rotate_270 and reflect are defined elsewhere in the Isabelle environment to perform the appropriate geometric transformations.
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "Q' = rotate_270 M (reflect Q)"
shows  "Q' = (2, 5)"

Note: Here we assume that the functions rotate_270 and reflect are defined elsewhere in the Isabelle environment to perform the appropriate geometric transformations.
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given four points in a plane, M(2,5), N(6,5), P(6,7), and Q(2,7). If we reflect point Q and then rotate the resulting point 270 degrees around point M, we get a new point Q'. Find the coordinates of Q'. The final answer is Q' = (2,5).

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q R Q' :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate M 270"
and h5 : "Q' = reflect x=1 (R Q)"
shows  "Q' = (2, 5)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;

 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));

 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q R Q' :: "real*real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate M 270"
and h5 : "Q' = reflect x=1 (R Q)"
shows  "Q' = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given that points M, N, P, and Q are located at coordinates (2,5), (6,5), (6,7), and (2,7) respectively, and point R is the result of rotating point M by 270 degrees. If point Q' is the reflection of point Q in respect to the line x=1, what are the coordinates of point Q'? The final answer is (2,5).

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate_around_M_270_deg = (\<lambda>(x, y). (2 - (y - 5), x + 5 - 2))"
and h5 : "reflect_x_1 = (\<lambda>(x, y). (2 - x, y))"
shows  "reflect_x_1 (rotate_around_M_270_deg Q) = (2, 5)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate_around_M_270_deg = (\<lambda>(x, y). (2 - (y - 5), x + 5 - 2))"
and h5 : "reflect_x_1 = (\<lambda>(x, y). (2 - x, y))"
shows  "reflect_x_1 (rotate_around_M_270_deg Q) = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
Given five points M, N, P, Q, and R in a 2D plane where M=(2,5), N=(6,5), P=(6,7), Q=(2,7), and a rotation function 'rotate_around_M_270_deg' which rotates a point 270 degrees around M, and a reflection function 'reflect_x_1' which reflects a point along the vertical line x=1. 

Find the new coordinates of point Q after it is first rotated 270 degrees around point M and then reflected along the vertical line x=1. 

The final answer is (2,5).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate_270 M Q"
and h5 : "R = reflect_x_1 R"
shows  "R = (2, 5)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q R :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "R = rotate_270 M Q"
and h5 : "R = reflect_x_1 R"
shows  "R = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given the points M(2,5), N(6,5), P(6,7), and Q(2,7), find the point R such that R is the point obtained by rotating Q by 270 degrees about M and then reflecting the result in the line x=1. The final answer is R(2,5).

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate Q M 270 = Q'"
and h5 : "reflect Q' (1, 0) = Q"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;
 pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1; for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs);
 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate Q M 270 = Q'"
and h5 : "reflect Q' (1, 0) = Q"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given points M(2,5), N(6,5), P(6,7), and Q(2,7), if we rotate Q about M by 270 degrees to get Q' and then reflect Q' about the line y=0 to get Q, show that Q is (2,5).

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate M 270 Q = reflect (x=1) Q"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;

 draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead)); label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); [/asy] When we rotate $Q$ $270^\circ$ clockwise about $M$, we arrive at $Q'=(0,5)$: [asy] size(150); dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); dot((0,5)); label("$Q' (0,5)$",(0,5),W); draw((2,5)--(2,7));
 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "rotate M 270 Q = reflect (x=1) Q"
shows  "Q = (2, 5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given points M = (2, 5), N = (6, 5), P = (6, 7) and Q = (2, 7), if you rotate point Q about point M by 270 degrees and it is the same as reflecting point Q over the line x=1, then the coordinates of point Q must be (2, 5).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "Q' = rotate_270_clockwise M Q"
and h5 : "Q' = reflect_x=1 Q'"
shows  "Q' = (2,5)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Quadrilateral MNPQ has vertices with coordinates $M(2,5)$, $N(6, 5)$, $P(6, 7)$ and $Q(2, 7)$. When the figure is rotated clockwise $270^\circ$ around point $M$ and then reflected across the line $x = 1$, what are the coordinates of the final image of point $Q$? Express your answer as an ordered pair. The final Answer is (2,5)
 ### Proof
 Since the problem only asks for the final image of point $Q$, we only need to look at point $Q$ with respect to point $M$.
 We plot the two points below and connect them: [asy] dot((2,5)); dot((2,7)); label("$M (2,5)$",(2,5),E); label("$Q (2,7)$",(2,7),E); draw((2,5)--(2,7)); import graph; size(4.45cm); real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12;

 import graph; real lsf=0.5; pen dps=linewidth(0.7)+fontsize(10); defaultpen(dps); pen ds=black; real xmin=0,xmax=12,ymin=0,ymax=12; pen zzzzzz=rgb(0.6,0.6,0.6); /*grid*/ pen gs=linewidth(0.7)+zzzzzz; real gx=1,gy=1;
 for(real i=ceil(xmin/gx)*gx;i<=floor(xmax/gx)*gx;i+=gx) draw((i,ymin)--(i,ymax),gs); for(real i=ceil(ymin/gy)*gy;i<=floor(ymax/gy)*gy;i+=gy) draw((xmin,i)--(xmax,i),gs); draw((12.3,0)--(0,0)--(0,12.3),Arrows(TeXHead));
 label("$x$",(12.2,0),E); label("$y$",(0,12.2),N); draw(Arc((2,5),2,0,-90)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,90,0)); draw(Arc((2,5),2,180,270)); [/asy] Reflecting $Q'=(0,5)$ about the line $x=1$ yields $Q''=\boxed{(2,5)}$.
 Notice that entirely by coincidence, this is the same as point $M$.
 *)

theorem
fixes M N P Q Q' :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "M = (2, 5)"
and h1 : "N = (6, 5)"
and h2 : "P = (6, 7)"
and h3 : "Q = (2, 7)"
and h4 : "Q' = rotate_270_clockwise M Q"
and h5 : "Q' = reflect_x=1 Q'"
shows  "Q' = (2,5)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If M is the point (2,5), N is the point (6,5), P is the point (6,7), and Q is the point (2,7), then find Q' such that Q' is the result of rotating Q 270 degrees clockwise about M and reflecting Q' in the line x=1. The final answer is the point (2,5).
